Award.AwardTitle: International Research Fellowship Program: Reproductive Morphology and Anatomy, and Molecular Phylogeny of the Aquifoliales
Award.AbstractNarration: The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad. This award will support an eleven-month research fellowship by Dr. Melanie Schori to work with Dr. Paula Rudall at the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew in the United Kingdom. Reproductive morphology, anatomy, and development provide insights into relationships among genera as well as among major lineages of plants. The order Aquifoliales has recently been shown to be basal to Asterales, Apiales, and Dipsacales. Aquifoliales contains five families, including the hollies, and certain members exhibit unusual floral and fruiting diversity. Representatives of each genus are being examined to assess differences in floral embryology, development, and fruit anatomy. Reproductive characters are being mapped onto a three-gene phylogeny so characters can be examined in a phylogenetic context to determine character polarities and patterns of evolution within the Aquifoliales. DNA data have significantly changed the current understanding of plant relationships, but molecular data are not always sufficient to resolve finer-scale relationships. Understanding relationships is crucial for applications from species identification and conservation to plant breeding. Structure and development, especially of reproductive features, tend to be conserved and provide valuable information about patterns of evolution. However, the reproductive anatomy and development of most plants have not been studied. Researchers are returning to anatomical studies to answer questions about relationships. The research funded by this project will answer questions about relationships and unique flower and fruit types in the hollies and their relatives. In addition, its valuable data will be used by researchers studying flower and fruit diversity and evolution in related economically important groups like the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and the carrot family (Apiaceae).

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research focused on the characteristics and anatomy of flowers and fruits in Aquifoliales, the group of plants that includes hollies. This group includes 20 different genera, most of which occur in the Old World Tropics. I examined pollen, surface features of flowers, internal anatomy of flowers and fruits, and relationships among these plants. Scientists have only recently established that Aquifoliales form a natural group of closely related plants, and most of the features I studied have never been examined before. Fifteen genera can be distinguished by their pollen alone, and these results will help researchers who use pollen to study climate change and the distribution of plants in ancient times. Several genera had irregular or sterile pollen grains, suggesting that pollen formation is abnormal. This might be due to hybridization or high chromosome numbers, and could provide information on how some of these plants evolved. Pollen samples from one genus of trees from Vietnam, Thailand, and China showed striking differences in patterning. These trees cannot be easily distinguished by their leaves or flowers, but pollen may provide a way to identify different species and determine whether any are rare or endangered. Flowers and fruits of Aquifoliales have a number of unusual features, and these features can help separate and characterize the five families in the group. Seven genera have a large fleshy appendage on their fruits, a feature that is only found in one genus outside of Aquifoliales. The appendage attracts birds and other animals that can spread seeds. The origin and structure of the appendage, previously unknown, demonstrate that all seven genera have the same type of appendage. DNA sequence data from genera in Aquifoliales should show how they are related, determine whether features like the appendage had a single origin within the group, and provide information on patterns of reproductive evolution among the families and genera of Aquifoliales.

My research was conducted at the Jodrell Laboratory, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, UK, one of the world’s leading botanical institutions. I received extensive training on techniques used to study anatomy and am now teaching students in the US on these techniques. I also mentored and established connections with students and researchers from the UK, Brazil, Malaysia, and Turkey. My results will be published in several scientific articles, and most of my data and research materials will be available to the public. Kew maintains a collection of pollen slides that can be used by researchers. Microscope slides of fruit sections will be kept at Kew’s Millennium Seed Bank, where scientists study fruits and seeds. DNA sequence data will be publically available in GenBank, an on-line database, and pollen images will be hosted by PalDat, a searchable database of pollen images.
